Chapter 4: Inviting the TathÄgata (2)
At that time, Anavatapta himself, together with his retinue, bowed to the World-Honored One, knelt on their right knees, joined their palms, and said to the Buddha:

We respectfully invite the Heavenly Honored One to turn your spiritual light and go to the great pond of no heat. For three months, we wish to make offerings to the Holy Honored One, the Bodhisattvas who have accomplished the spiritual powers, and the foremost disciples!
Please accept our invitation out of compassion.
The reason is this:
When we make offerings to the Perfectly Enlightened One, how can we be worthy of the TathÄgata's dignity?
We hope to attain hearing about the supreme transformation of tranquility. Only by this Dharma can we make offerings.
We wish to hear this kind of Dharma again and again, to always be delighted. This is how we should make offerings to the Three Jewels!
At that time, the World-Honored One did not accept their invitation.
Again requested:
February?
The TathÄgata did not agree;
May I request to listen for one month?
The World-Honored One could not be persuaded;
May I respectfully accept for half a month?
The World-Honored One silently accepted it.

Then the Dragon King, together with his retinue, saw the Venerable accept the invitation, and with joy and delight, a good mind was finally born. He circumambulated the Buddha three times, caused thunder and clouds to shake, and rained lightly, covering the entire world. In an instant, he returned to the palace.
At that time, Anan arrived at the main hall and immediately summoned the five hundred eldest sons, whose names were:

Good Tooth, Good Giving, Good Intention, Good Light, Able to Extinguish, Silent Appearance, Moving, Great Power, Sweet Power, Sweet Strategy, Sweet Virtue, Universal Praise, Powerful Courage, Holding Honey, Power of Patience, Practicing Auspiciousness;
In this way, the five hundred eldest sons had already planted the unsurpassed true path in the past.
The king said to them:
Moreover, all of you children!

I have now invited the TathÄgata, the Unattached, the Perfectly Enlightened One, together with the assembly of bodhisattvas and disciples, for the duration of half a month. The World-Honored One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, out of great compassion, has accepted the invitation.
You should all unify your minds, encourage each other, and increase your respect for the World-Honored One, the TathÄgata!

Be mindful of impermanence, each of you be tranquil, humble, reverent, and wait for the TathÄgata. You should abandon lustful desires, playful amusements, greed, anger, and harmfulness, and be free from desires for form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
Why is this?

The World-Honored One is without desire and yet detailed and at ease, benevolent and elegant, true and correct, following tranquility and calmness, manifesting and possessing all virtues, attended by a retinue, with immeasurable dignified appearances, all upholding the true and essential precepts of the buddhas.
For this reason, you should not enter the palace for half a month, and should eliminate thoughts of lust, anger, and ignorance.

Moreover, because the TathÄgata proclaims the Dharma, there will certainly be bodhisattvas with spiritual powers from other directions, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, the world-protectors, and the sons of the pure heavens who will all come to the assembly. You should diligently remember to widely bestow what is beautiful and splendid, and adorn it with utmost care, so that the assembly will rejoice upon seeing the transformation. This is truly making offerings to the TathÄgata.

At that time, after Anantadhvaja had given these instructions, he immediately transformed a flawless pure beryl seat for the World-Honored One in the Anavatapta Pond at the foot of the snow mountains, which was seven hundred yojanas long and wide, extremely wonderful, and surrounded by eighty-four thousand jeweled trees of various treasures, adorned with various precious gems, fresh and splendid, with a hundred colors shining brightly, emitting beautiful fragrances.

Between the trees, there were transformed 84,000 seven-jeweled halls, with a brilliant luster of various treasures, extremely wonderful and unparalleled. Ten thousand jeweled canopies were set up, and extraordinary and wonderful red pearl necklaces were hung.
Above the halls were lion thrones, 84,000 in number, all extremely tall and wide. Precious bedding and seats were arranged, and various treasures were used for the canopies.

In each of the halls there were two thousand dragons and court ladies, their complexions exquisite and their figures incomparably beautiful. Their faces were like lotus flowers, their mouths exuded fragrant incense, and they held various flowers, powdered incense, and ointments. They played various musical instruments to sing the Buddha's virtues and delight the assembly. In the sky above, they conjured a great jeweled canopy, covering an area of a thousand yojanas and extending over the assembly. The canopy was inlaid with precious gems and various colors, and it hung with beautiful silk banners. Between the banners were suspended jeweled bells, and when the gentle breeze blew, their sound surpassed all music. They prepared a hundred flavors of food and drink.

After performing these transformations, together with his retinue, he respectfully joined his palms, knelt on one knee towards the Buddha, and from afar addressed the Honored One, expressing his intention with a eulogy:ğŸ”½The treasury of wisdom knows the accumulation of wealth and virtue, the wisdom reaches without attachment, and the light guides the assembly;
The wisdom is vast and all-pervading, without obstruction, and the supreme power of wisdom emits divine light.
The mind of wisdom and understanding is only for the great and virtuous!
One should contemplate the various beings in the ten directions;
The supreme divine honored one accepts my invitation, thinking to open up compassion and only then to come.
Contentment, non-greed, and easy support, auspicious blessings, the true and correct teacher of the noble path;
Good conduct, sincerity, and understanding the intentions of the assembly, when the time has come it is appropriate to invite the honored one.
His virtues are universally praised, and his conduct is equal to a king, creating unsolicited friends and giving rise to universal concern;
The most benevolent and pure one surpasses the sky, and the arrangements are completed, so I deceive the divine honored one!
Dominating the ten directions, fiercely upholding the world, the Buddha's work is equal to the eighteen;
The foremost in liberating the assembly, with the practice of leaping with compassion, I wish to be with the assembly and be favored by him at this time.
The body with a wondrous and upright appearance, various beautiful patterns embroidered with flowers;
Delighting in the joy of giving the Dharma as a gift, the most benevolent and supreme guide, I wish to observe the time.
The pure Brahma voice thunders, with the mournful cry of a phoenix and the gait of a lion;
The wonderful voice is complete, delighting all lands, with the multitude's mind eagerly awaiting, wishing for you to look upon them in time.
The Buddha land of the trichiliocosm is unequaled, with none able to know the TathÄgata's mind;
The sagely honored one clearly sees the conduct of sentient beings, always in accordance with the time descending here.
Knowing the time, universally responding with the intention of expedient transformation, penetratingly understanding sentient beings' sagely vows;
The conduct of careful consideration, with eyes bright and beautiful, the majestic power subduing the feet, wishing to turn the light back.
Sentient beings are extremely numerous, universally thirsting and yearning, with the ten powers holding the force, majesty without arrogance;
The great benevolent virtue is lofty and courageous, with the sagely nature thus descending to play here.
Shame and auspiciousness are complete, with virtue supreme, how could it be to save and nurture universally without limit?
The teacher and friend are unparalleled, harmonizing with the multitude, transforming dragons in the hundreds of millions, giving rise to compassion.
You understand all practices and respond to people's minds;
You open and scatter, revealing only the Heavenly Honored One!
The time has come for you to display your spiritual powers and ascend.
At that time, the World-Honored One knew that the time for Anantadhvaja's invitation had arrived. He told the bhiká¹£us:

Put on your robes and carry your bowls. Leave those who should stay behind. When the dragon king Anavatapta kneels and announces the time, you should accept the invitation for half a month. It is appropriate to go there immediately.

At that time, 84,000 bodhisattvas all had great spiritual powers, virtues, and accomplished fruits. 2,000 disciples also had superior spiritual abilities. They surrounded the World-Honored One and led the way. The TathÄgata suddenly ascended into the sky from the peak of Vulture Peak, advancing with spiritual power. His body emitted countless hundreds of thousands of lights, illuminating the entire trichiliocosm, making it all bright and clear.
The gods of the desire realm and form realm all saw the World-Honored One flying through the sky with countless lights, and they said to each other:

The gods have brought the king of Anavatapta to the place where the Dharma will be taught and the profound will be expounded to the utmost, and have caused the Tathagata to be surrounded by the assembly. In the middle of that month, many hundreds of thousands of gods will see the World-Honored One and hear the Dharma teachings, and will also witness the transformations manifested by the adornments set up by Anavatapta, causing the World-Honored One to purposely visit there.

At that time, each of the celestial sons had the thought to make offerings to the Tathagata, some wishing to scatter flowers, some to rain down famous incense, some to offer heavenly music to sing the Buddha's virtues;
some also hung banners, flags, canopies, and silks following the Tathagata!
The World-Honored One's bodily radiance was dazzling and bright, shining more than the light of the sun, moon, stars, pure colors, and the gods.

The Buddha's holy majestic radiance was immeasurable. His faculties were concentrated, tranquil, and his conduct was leisurely and at ease. The various transformations of the majesty of the Shakra, Brahma, and the Four Heavenly Kings followed and attended the Tathagata.
At that time, the World-Honored One arrived at the foot of the snow mountains and stayed on the right side. He then told the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana:
You go to the palace of King Anavatapta and proclaim to him:
'The TathÄgata has already arrived. You may enter at this time.'

Thereupon, the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana, receiving the Buddha's spiritual power, suddenly moved to the great pond of Anavatapta, appearing in the sky seven zhang above the ground. His transformed body was like the king of garuá¸as, standing above the palace of the nÄga king Anavatapta, and he then told the king:
The TathÄgata has arrived.
The assembly of nÄgas and their female attendants were all startled, frightened, and terrified, with their hair standing on end. They hid in various places and said to each other:
Since the beginning of this pond, there have been no garuá¸as. Where did this one come from?
At that time, Anavatapta told the palace people, princes, and their relatives to comfort them, saying:
Just rest assured, do not be afraid, this is the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana!
He is carrying out the TathÄgata's mission, manifesting spiritual powers.
The Venerable MaudgalyÄyana arrived there, delivered the message, and returned to the World-Honored One.

At that time, Anavatapta then, together with his retinueâ€”the princes, ministers, people, wives, and court ladiesâ€”the entire palace surrounded him, each offering famous flowers, fine powdered incense, various ointments, banners, canopies, silk banners, and various harmonious musical performances, and advanced to welcome the Perfectly Enlightened One.
At that time, the World-Honored One!
Surrounded by the bodhisattvas, disciples, devas, nÄgas, and honored spirits, they all advanced together to the vast seat arranged by Anavatapta.
After arriving, he immediately sat on the lofty and prominent lion seat, followed by the bodhisattvas, and then the disciples all sat down.

At that time, the dragon king observed that the World-Honored One, the bodhisattvas, disciples, and the assembly were all seated and still, and his mind gave rise to immeasurable joy within. He immediately, together with his retinue, held various offerings in his hands. The food and drink he prepared surpassed the world's delicacies, with a hundred kinds of heavenly flavors, which he used to make offerings to the Buddha, bodhisattvas, disciples, and the entire assembly, causing them all to be fully satisfied.
After the World-Honored One, the bodhisattvas, and the disciples had finished their meal, they immediately each washed their bowls.
Seeing that the assembly had all finished, Anantadhvaja then said to the TathÄgata:
I wish to hear the Dharma being spoken.
Thereupon, the World-Honored One, after the sun had shifted to the afternoon, arose from his concentration and sat upright to speak the Dharma.
The entire assembly that had come filled a thousand yojanas, from the ground to above, without any empty gaps. Devas, nÄgas, spirits, humans, and non-humans surrounded the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Everyone in the assembly was filled with joy.
Chapter 5: The Practice of Non-Desire (2) Chapter 5: The Practice of Non-Desire, Part 5 At that time, the dragon king joyfully stepped forward and knelt, respectfully saying to the Buddha:
I only wish that the World-Honored One!

For the sake of this assembly, speak the Dharma as appropriate, enabling all to escape from birth and death, diligently removing the suffering of the five aggregates due to attachment, the deluded and defiled conduct of afflictions, causing them to forever be without the bonds of the three poisons, and enabling the dragons to abandon wrong views and darkness, subdue their minds, greatly attain utmost goodness, and have joy, deeply practicing the bodhisattva path.
Later, whether the Tathagata is present or has passed away, we will protect and uphold the true Dharma in our countries and cities.
Then the World-Honored One praised the dragon king, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Ananta King!

Listen carefully to its meaning, diligently contemplate it, and disseminate it. I will explain it extensively, enabling the assembly to avoid many painful roots of miscellaneous thoughts and doubts in their consciousness, and to understand universal wisdom and ascend to roam the three realms.
At that time, the dragon king said:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear the extensive explanation and will uphold and practice it.
At that time, the Holy Venerable told the dragon king:
There is one Dharma practice that bodhisattvas should cultivate, and they will be greatly respected by the gods and people of the world.
What is that one?
Aspiring to cultivate the profound Dharma, practicing without desire.
What is meant by the profound Dharma practice of being without desire?
In this way, O Dragon King!

Bodhisattvas rely on the absence of causes and conditions, leaving behind the two extremes of views. Knowing existence and non-existence, they see all dharmas. Relying on causes and conditions, they do not see any dharmas that are not produced by conditions. They think like this:
'Those who rely on causes and conditions have no reliance on conditions, and they do not rely on Mara.
As for the basis and conditions, they do not speak of 'I' or 'mine.'
Moreover, within the basis and conditions there is no self or 'mine,' the basis and conditions have no master and are also not grasped and guarded.
'If one understands the arising of dependent origination, one can quickly and easily attain the four kinds of mindfulness.'
What are the four?

Relying on the ultimate meaning and not on literary embellishment, relying on the practice of wisdom and not on conceptual thoughts, relying on sÅ«tras that accord with the meaning and not on grasping, relying on mindfulness of the Dharma and not on the person.
What is meant by 'meaning'?
What is meant by 'wisdom'?
What is meant by 'accordance with the meaning'?
What is meant by 'mindfulness of the Dharma'?
Meaning refers to the meaning of emptiness;
The meaning of signlessness is not grasping at false views;
The meaning of wishlessness is not being attached to conceptual thoughts, not being attached to the three realms, and not being attached to counting;

Moreover, the meaning is that in regard to Dharma and non-Dharma, there is no duality. Sound is unattainable, thoughts are without thoughts, the realm of Dharma is without abiding, because there is no self. The sounds of life and lifespan are false and nonexistent.
Moreover, for the sake of meaning, the meaning of Dharma is the meaning of non-desire.
What is it that bodhisattvas do for the meaning of Dharma?
It is the meaning of no eyes and forms, ears and sounds, noses and smells, tongues and tastes, bodies and sensations, and mind and dharmas;
The meaning of not producing forms, the meaning of not extinguishing forms;
The meaning of not being feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, and also the meaning of not producing or extinguishing the activities of consciousness;
Also the meaning of not being desire, form, or formlessness, and also the meaning of not producing or extinguishing desire, form, or formlessness;
Also the meaning of no self, also the meaning of no view of self or attachment to people;
The meaning of no person, also the meaning of not being attached to the view of entering a person;

They also do not become attached to the meaning of entering the Buddha's body, nor do they become attached to the meaning of entering the Dharma, nor do they become attached to the meaning of entering into calculations;
They also do not have the meaning of attachment to giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, and wisdom.
Understanding the meaning of entering all dharmas is called the meaning of Dharma for bodhisattvas.
Not regressing from this meaning is called the meaning.
What is called wisdom?
It is said:
Wisdom of the non-arising of suffering;
Wisdom of the non-thought of accumulation;
Wisdom of the complete exhaustion of cessation;
Wisdom of the non-intention of the path.
Wisdom of not destroying the nature of dharmas in the illusory dharmas of the aggregates;

Wisdom of taking the emptiness of the various faculties as wisdom, understanding and entering the various dharmas, clearly knowing the faculties of sentient beings, and fully possessing the wisdom of intention and mindfulness.
In the various intentions of cessation, not intending and not thinking;
In the various intentions of elimination, equally good and bad;
In the various spiritual powers, the wisdom of establishing body and mind;
Also, in the various faculties, the wisdom of understanding lightness and heaviness;
The wisdom of arousing the mind of enlightenment and understanding all dharmas;
The wisdom of already subduing and taming the powers.

The wisdom of the path being innumerable and extinguishing quiescence, the wisdom of contemplating separate dharmas, the wisdom of originally not arising, the wisdom of not coming, the wisdom of not abiding in the middle;

The wisdom of the body being like a reflection, the wisdom of speech being like an echo, the wisdom of the mind and dharmas being like an illusion - this is called the bodhisattva's penetrating wisdom.
Moreover, what is meant by the meaning of guiding scriptures?

From these causes and conditions, one gives rise to the extinction of ignorance, the extinction of old age and death, and the selflessness of self, person, and life, and deeply understands all things.
If the TathÄgata and self are both not true dharmas, then one gives rise to the three gates of liberation.

Seeking the three non-attachments equally in the three times, namely, seeing that all dharmas are originally unborn, and attaining equal cessation by understanding and knowing, free from worldly emotions and attitudes, the wisdom of the bodhisattva's coming, the perfection of wisdom, being without doubt in all thoughts, should enter this practice, this is called conforming to the meaning;
Without going or coming, and also without coming from anywhere, nirvana is unconditioned and does not have going or coming, this is called conforming to the meaning.
What is meant by according with the Dharma?

Whether the TathÄgatas appear in the world or not, the Dharma body always abides. This is called the TathÄgata's suchness, originally non-existent, without increase or decrease, non-dual and without duality, the ultimate reality of dharmas, which is called according with the Dharma.
Not destroying the practice of retribution, and the Dharma of no retribution, this is called according with the Dharma.
The Mahayana is due to the six pÄramitÄs;
The Pratyekabuddha vehicle is liberated from causes and conditions;
The ÅšrÄvaka vehicle is liberated by relying on sounds, this is called according with the Dharma.
Giving leads to great blessings;
Observing precepts leads to rebirth in the heavens;
Extensive learning and great wisdom;
Concentration and mindfulness lead to liberation, this is called according with the Dharma.
Following practice without cultivation gives rise to birth and death, practicing purely and thoroughly establishes non-action, this is called according with the Dharma.
Foolishness is the power of desire;
Wisdom is the power of insight, this is called according with the Dharma.
All dharmas rely on the nature of dharmas.
In this way, Dragon King!

Those who rely on causes and conditions to give rise to birth should attain the four kinds of reliance, those who rely on causes and conditions do not rely on the annihilation or attachment of existence and non-existence, this is called:
Those who see the arising of causes and conditions see all dharmas;
Those who see the Dharma see the TathÄgata!ğŸ”½Why is it so?
Because of causes and conditions.
Dragon King!
Equally arising without arising, the Dharma is equal and unattached to non-dharma.
Moreover, the TathÄgata!
It is also the arising of the causes and conditions of non-attachment, and there is no arising, the Dharma cannot be attained, and one who realizes the Dharma is the TathÄgata!
In the arising of causes and conditions, the wisdom eye sees it;
The one who sees with the wisdom eye is the various dharmas;
The one who sees the various dharmas is the TathÄgata!
This is called:
One who sees the arising of causes and conditions sees the Dharma, and one who sees the Dharma sees the TathÄgata!
Moreover, the TathÄgata sees the Dharma with the Dharma.
In this way, Dragon King!
If one should be liberated by practicing this Dharma, this is called a bodhisattva without desirous practice.
Moreover, Dragon King!

A bodhisattva without desire does not create desirous habits, delights in the sages and abandons the non-sages, diligently aspires to protect the sage's lineage, widely combines all wisdom to protect the Dharma, cultivates extensive learning, and aspires to plant the unforgetting.

They do not abandon the body of precepts, the body of wisdom is unshakable, the body of concentration is unmoving, they attain excellent stability in the body of wisdom, and the body of liberation, wisdom, and insight is strong and difficult to turn back, due to the liberation, wisdom, and insight.
Moreover, Dragon King!

Bodhisattvas without desire attain the meaning of crossing over the innumerable correct teachings of the Buddha, and are also endowed with the essential wisdom of the innumerable buddhas, and the inexhaustible eloquence of the buddhas, attain the immeasurable spiritual powers of the buddhas, and attain the innumerable expedient understandings of the buddhas, universally enter the practices of innumerable sentient beings, transcend innumerable buddha lands, and thereby see innumerable hundreds of thousands of tathÄgatas, due to being able to listen to and hear innumerable teachings, attain innumerable meanings and penetrate innumerable wisdoms, understand innumerable practices and liberate innumerable sentient beings.
If it is so, Dragon King!
Bodhisattvas without desire should always be pure, exhaust all defilements, their virtues are immeasurable, they are free in the three realms and are not attached to anything.
Why is it so?
Because they are born from the mind itself, free from desires.
There are three things born from the mind.
What are the three?
Born from desire, born from love, and born from arising.
There are also three kinds of birth:
Observing arising, observing arising, and observing the mind without abode.
There are also three kinds of birth:
Extinction, tranquility, and concentration, understanding observation, and practicing in accordance with the Dharma.
There are also three kinds of birth:
Virtuous, benevolent, and disciplined, taking tranquility as birth.
There are also three things:
Born from upright practice, without flattery, benevolent, gentle, and patient.
There are also three things:
Without hesitation or doubt, following goodness without coarseness, content and easy to support.
There are also three things:
Born from emptiness, also from the absence of conceptualization, and from the absence of wishes.
There are also three things:

The various dharmas that arise from the mind are impermanent, arising from the mind; the various dharmas are all suffering, also arising from the mind; the various dharmas are without self, also arising from the mind.
There are also three things:
And arising from the mind are the various dharmas that are impermanent, the various dharmas that are without self, and the cessation of conditioned existence.
All arise from the mind.
If it is so, Dragon King!
Bodhisattvas!
The cessation of equality is also born from the mind, namely:
Not abandoning the mind of universal wisdom, practicing equally all, because of great kindness;
Not abandoning sentient beings, because of the mind of great compassion;
Not wearying of birth and death, because of great joy;
Equally leaving behind joy and anger, because of great protection;
All giving of wisdom without expecting reward;
Because the practice of the precepts is complete in virtue and meaning.

They avoid their own faults and do not discuss the shortcomings of others. They are able to endure the various unwholesome actions of sentient beings. They wish to cause the minds of others to be as firm as vajra, to gather and accumulate the roots of goodness and virtues, and to not spare their bodies and lives in order to attain all meditative absorptions and mental states without weariness. They do not give rise to anything through meditative absorption, and with wisdom and skillful means they follow sentient beings, and with their true wisdom they liberate those whose minds are liberated.

Those who wish to understand the vehicles of the hearers and solitary realizers manifest mindfulness of the Buddha's teachings and seek the Buddha's teachings. Because their minds are able to endure suffering and extensively proclaim the Dharma, they are despised and abandoned by the multitude who benefit and respect them. Their aspirations are replete with all characteristics and their virtuous conduct is without weariness. They are filled with wisdom and diligently seek much learning.
Because they cultivate good friends, they encounter good and virtuous friends.
Because they are humble and respectful, they attain the practice of humility.
Because they subdue arrogance, they subdue arrogance.
Because their aspirations and conduct are complete, they fulfill their intended conduct.
Because they are without deceit, they are free from deceit.
Because their words and actions accord, they are without deception.
Because of cultivating sincerity and faith, it is said to abide in faith;
Because of being free from deception, false speech is eliminated;
Because of giving rise to sincerity and faith, the mind is subdued in faith.
Thus, Dragon King!
If there are bodhisattvas who give rise to this mind, this is called being without desire.
Moreover, Dragon King!
Demons cannot find an opportunity to take advantage of bodhisattvas who are without desire.
Why is this?
Because those bodhisattvas should be without limits, and they also do not practice limited dharmas.
What are those called limited dharmas?
Desire, anger, and delusion are all limited. Bodhisattvas are not attached to these, and this is called being without limits.
The vehicle of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is limited. Bodhisattvas who abide in the mind of universal wisdom, demons can never find an opportunity to take advantage of their limits.
Mindfulness and non-mindfulness are limited thoughts. Bodhisattvas are free from the various thoughts and responses.
In this way, MÄra cannot find an opportunity to harm such a bodhisattva.
Thus it is, Dragon King!
There are two demonic matters that bodhisattvas should deeply understand and also distance themselves from.
What are the two matters?
Lacking a reverent and respectful mind towards teachers and friends, and placing oneself in a lofty position with great arrogance and contempt for others - these are considered the two.
There are also two demonic matters:
Abandoning the bodhisattva's treasury of the six perfections, and instead delighting in and personally practicing the teachings of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
There are also two matters.
What are the two?
Lacking wisdom while wishing to practice skillful means, and delighting in close association with sentient beings who have fallen into attachment and views - there are also two matters:
Having little learning and wisdom, yet considering oneself to be wise and enlightened, and though possessing extensive knowledge, being self-important within it.
There are also two matters:
Falsely giving rise to noble status with very few virtues, and if cultivating virtuous practices, delighting in the Lesser Vehicle.
There are also two matters:
The true Dharma is not protected, and sentient beings are not liberated.
There are two more things:
Not delighting in practicing with the bodhisattvas and those with penetrating wisdom, exclusively slandering the pure and lofty bodhisattvas, and often creating obstructions for the Dharma masters;
Also obstructing the teacher's instructions and being full of flattery.
There are two more demonic activities:
Abandoning all roots of virtue and keeping an undutiful mind.
There are two more things:
Although dwelling in seclusion, harboring thoughts of the three poisons and always having a confused mind; if wandering in towns and cities, having a greedy mind.
There are two more things:
Explaining profound and essential Dharma to those who are not suitable recipients, and not explaining what should be explained.
There are two more things:
Not being aware of demonic activities, and being far from the intention of universal wisdom, often confused.
Thus, Dragon King!
The appearances of those demonic activities are like this, and the bodhisattvas without desires are forever free from them.
Moreover, Dragon King!

If there are bodhisattvas who cultivate pure practices, they should be free from desire and attain the sixteen great powers of bodhisattvas, using these powers to subdue their own minds and transform sentient beings.
What are the sixteen powers of bodhisattvas?
It is said:

Attaining the power of will, the power of mind, the power of practice, the power of shame, the power of strength, the power of upholding, the power of wisdom, the power of virtue, the power of eloquence, the power of form, the power of body, the power of wealth, the power of mind, the power of spirit, the power of propagating the Dharma, and the power of subduing the power of demons.
Bodhisattvas free from desire attain these sixteen great powers of bodhisattvas.
What is the power of will for bodhisattvas?
Thus it is, Dragon King!ğŸ”½The power of will of bodhisattvas is able to comprehend all that is spoken by the buddhas and uphold it in total. This is called the power of will.
This bodhisattva's mind accords with the practices of the buddhas and is unobstructed towards all sentient beings. This is called the power of mind.
Understanding all sounds and comprehending all meanings is called the power of practice.
Separating from all evil practices and being endowed with various virtuous dharmas is the power of shame.
Not engaging in non-practice due to all difficulties is the power of strength.
Billions of demon soldiers do not dare to confront it, which is the power of wisdom.
Penetrating the dharmas of upholding and expounding them equally without forgetting is the power of upholding.
Not forgetting what is to be said for hundreds of thousands of kalpas without attachment, unobstructed and uninterrupted, in accordance with understanding all dharmas, is the power of eloquence.
If the various Åšakras, BrahmÄs, and Four Heavenly Kings go to the bodhisattva, they are overwhelmed and lose their color. This is the power of uprightness;
The treasures that can be thought of and wished for arrive as soon as one thinks of them. This is the power of wealth.
Surpassing all non-Buddhists and being alone in the middle as the most honored, this is the power of the body.
